channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: A remembrance of longtime CBS reporter and White House correspondent Mark Knoller
item.description: The White House Press Corps lost an icon this weekend. A remembrance of longtime CBS News reporter Mark Knoller.

item.title: College Game Day personality Lee Corso is retiring
item.description: On Saturday, the college football personality Lee Corso announced he was retiring from the broadcast and the network he joined back in 1987.

item.title: An emergency room doctor describes what the changes at the CDC could mean for public health
item.description: The Trump Administration has made significant changes to the departments in charge of public health. Dr. Craig Spencer, an emergency medicine physician who teaches public health policy at Brown University, discusses the impact he expects on the health of average Americans and for the future of public health research.

item.title: The best and worst of movies about high school
item.description: A look at the movies that authentically reflect the high school experience.

item.title: Israeli takeover of Gaza City is under way
item.description: The Israeli military says an order for nearly a million people to march south is "inevitable" -- and the assault has already begun.

item.title: Music on the porch brings joy to neighborhoods
item.description: The last Saturday in August is Play Music on the Porch Day. PeopleÂ register their porch parties online, and create some free neighborhood music and joy.

item.title: Surprising lessons from studies about post-Katrina trauma
item.description: Hurricane Katrina caused widespread trauma and dislocation. Researchers who followed survivors to track the mental health impacts of the storm found that while the trauma of Katrina caused elevated levels of mental health symptoms, many of the survivors reported personally growing from those losses.

item.title: A group of unhoused people fight for a tiny plot of land and a radical idea
item.description: A discussion with KQED's Snap Judgment team about the podcast A Tiny Plot that follows a group of homeless people in Oakland and their fight for their own plot of land from the city.

item.title: Friday night football brings healing in Kerrville
item.description: Still recovering from devastating July flash flooding, the Kerrville community gathered for the Texas tradition of high school football Friday night. As Texas Public Radio's David Martin Davies reports, the Tivy Antler varsity football team took on Del Rio in their season opener at Kerrville's Antler Stadium, the same location that was a volunteer hub after the July 4th flooding and where a recent massive memorial was held.

item.title: How to maintain long-lasting friendships
item.description: Why do some friendships survive for decades, while others fade away? NPR Life Kit host Marielle Segarra has tips on how to maintain long-lasting friendships, even in the busy seasons of our lives.
